Problem:
Consider a complex-valued function \\( z(t) = x(t) + iy(t) \\) governed by the differential equation \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Mz \\), where M is a constant complex matrix. The transformation specified by \\( g(z) = e^{Nt}z \\), where N is another constant complex matrix, is applied to study the behavior of the function over time t.

If \\( g(z) \\) is applied to an initial complex vector \\( z_0 \\) at t = 0, and then allowed to evolve under \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Mz \\) without any further intervention, will the resulting \\( z(t) \\) at any later time t = T be the same as if \\( z_0 \\) was directly evolved under \\( \\frac{dz}{dt} = Mz \\)?
Explanation: Applying \\( g(z) \\) modifies the initial state of the system by altering its phase and magnitude depending on the structure and coefficients of N. Given that \\( e^{Nt} \\) does not necessarily commute with M, the trajectory of \\( z(t) \\) will differ when it evolves from the transformed initial state.
